about.title: About Me
about.content: I'm a Python and SQL wizard who dabbles in JavaScript, C++, HTML, and CSS. When I'm not coding, I'm rollerskating, juggling, or petting my cats. My past gigs include data ops engineering, game dev team leading, teaching data science and even brewing beer. Once I was a barman. I've pretty much done it all.

work.name: Current Gig: Data Ops Engineer at Blueskeye AI
work.content: At Blueskeye AI I began as a mere Junior before being stripped of the Junior label after three months. I overhauled our inefficient annotation platform, building a robust modular system for creating annotation tools and migrating our annotation database from Firestore NoSQL to PostgreSQL. I designed and deployed a scalable, maintainable database and built a long term data warehousing solution for annotation storage. I've also processed a hell of a lot of video data and automated away all the boring crap with a bespoke Python library to make life easier for everyone.

work.name: Side Gig: Teaching Assistant at Le Wagon
work.content: Taught bootcamp student about Data Science, from those who thought Python was just a snake, right through to those who were ready to deploy real-world projects.

work.name: Past Gig: Game Development Team Lead at Date & Game
work.content: Created and maintained an online multiplayer framework for integration with a dating app, with fancy features such as world state synchronisation, race condition prevention, and resynchronisation. Collaborated with our backend team, pixel artist and game designer to create memorable experiences for our users. Trained up our new recruits and managed our team's workflow.

work.name: Past Gig: Head Brewer at Matlock Worlds Farm Brewery
work.content: Before I was a data wizard, I was a beer wizard. I managed our brewing schedule, stock levels, and quality control. Designed two award winning beers along the way, including one with Victorian heritage barley Chevallier (pretty cool, ask me about it).

projects.name: Early Development: Sokobanvania (Working Title)
projects.content: Ever played Chip's Challenge? Ever thought 'what if this game were open-world? Someone should make that'. Yeah, me too. Welcome to Sokobania - a seamless, dynamically loaded open world puzzle game that mashes up block pushing with exploration. Features include an undo system and childlike coloured pencil artwork.

projects.name: Coding Heaven: A Comedy Coding Blog
projects.content: Fed up of drab coding blogs? Me too. That's why I created Coding Heaven - a blog that finds joy in coding. I've tackled absurdities such as automated stealing of Advent of Code solutions, determining if a number is odd or even in Brainfuck, turning Fizz Buzz into something that sounds sort of like music and creating the universal 'Hello, World!' equation. It's coding, but fun.

projects.name: Blueskeye Annotation Tooling Suite (BATS)
projects.content: When I began work at Blueskeye I inherited a web-based annotation tool. It was like a car with square wheels (it did't work very well). I rebuilt it using clean, reusable classes and smart inheritence. The result is a bespoke, extensible annotation suite that supports a massive range of tools, let's us deploy new features in hours (not weeks) and handles hundreds of thousands of annotations (and no square wheels!). Data retrieval times have been reduced and refactored to allow videos of any length and filesize to be annotated, removing bottlenecks for files over 10mb.

projects.name: Data Processing Python Library
projects.content: At work I wrangle video data. One hell of a lot of video data. After rewriting the same code for the billionth time, I decided to write a Python library to do it for me. Every function and feature in the library was built and tested using test-driven development (TDD), because breaking things is best avoided when dealing with terabytes of data. The result is a library that simplified complex data processing tasks down to a mere few lines of code, integrates seamlessly with our annotation data warehouse and can even be automated to continually process data whilst I sleep. Errors have been reduced by standardising the processing pipelines and with the addition of features such as auto-rotation to detect the way-upness of videos, resulting in a reduction of both processing time and time lost to mistakes. Laziness truly is the mother of invention.
